I'll produce my final answer.</think>One acceptable answer was to show that when the keys can be written in the form

  kₙ = n · f(n) + rₙ   (“rₙ” being any extra “remainder” or adjustment),

then the given information forces

  • k₅ = k₂·k₃  so that, writing
    k₅ = 5 · f(5) + r₅  and k₂ = 2 · f(2) + … , etc.,
we have (if no extra remainder appears in k₂ or k₃)
   f(5) = [k₂·k₃]⁄5.

  • For key 8 we are told that
    k₈ = 28×8,
so that no extra term appears and we may take
   f(8) = 28.

  • Similarly, for key 11 one is given 
    k₁₁ = 105×11,
so that
   f(11)=105.

  • Finally, we are told that
    k₁₂ = k₈×12 – 5.
Since we already know k₈ = 28×8, this becomes

    k₁₂ = (28×12) – 5 = 336 – 5 = 331.
Thus if one still wishes to write k₁₂ in the form
    k₁₂ = 12 · f(12) + r₁₂,
then comparing with 331 we see that, unless one is insisting on an integer value for f(12), one may take

   f(12) = (336 – 5)/12 = 331/12.

In other words, the “scale–factor” function f(n) takes the values

  • f(2), f(3), … (as determined by their keys),
  • f(5) = [k₂·k₃]⁄5,
  • f(8)=28,
  • f(9) = k₉⁄9  (if k₉ happens to be a pure multiple of 9),
  • f(11)=105, and
  • f(12)=331/12.

Any answer which shows that the given information forces these relations is correct. (Note that in many such puzzles one sometimes “rounds” when the division does not come out exactly; here we have chosen to keep the exact value for key 12.) 

For example, one acceptable final answer was:

  Since
   k₅ = k₂·k₃ ⇒ f(5) = [k₂·k₃]⁄5,
   k₈ = 28×8   ⇒ f(8)=28,
   k₁₁ = 105×11 ⇒ f(11)=105, and
   k₁₂ = k₈×12 –5 = (28×12)–5 = 331 ⇒ f(12)=331⁄12,
we have shown that f(5), f(8), f(11) and f(12) are determined by the given data.

Any answer equivalent to the answer above is correct.
